author: klarkc
title: Bring Cardano to the web with Vite
description: There a lot of barriers right now to begin to build a dapp. You must have a set of tools that have many ways to be installed.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposals' purpose is to make life easier for dapps developers, by having a tool to create template projects with simply running a command. This is overall a great idea and it will definately benefit the community. As a developer myself I believe it's a good idea to introduce the javascript ecosystem through plugins and other intermediate languages to the cardano ecosystem, because in this way, things won't look that scary for dealing with something entirely new. This proposal is definitely in the correct challenge setting and it could be used as a stepping stone by future developers to bootstrap them into an easy start at least. The one thing I'm not entirely sure about in this proposal is it's scalability. I see there's one guy at the moment planning to start doing all the work. While this is commendible it often leads to inability to cope with the incomming challenges due to lack of time and/or knowledge. In the case of Haskel the author admits he's a beginer in the language, and wouldn't be able to contribute too much there. The proposal deffinitely adds a missing part to the ecosystem and it's really the right way to go to start spreading to different ecosystems like the javascript one which is quite big. A lot of js developers would be happy to try out anything new as long as they can run a couple of known commands like npm install insert_project_name. This leads me to really trust in the impact this project would have. Automatic tooling and bootstraping and making everything easy to use is surely the way to go.
f6_assessments.q1:
The author of the proposer who plans to be the main contributer as well seems to have all the necessary knowledge to start off with this idea, but he'll need to find a haskel team mate and there's are hard to come by, based on my experience. Other than that I think the proposal is credible and has a good chance to be implemented and for the project to reach the end goal it has set for itself. It's commendable that the project author is so realistic about the things he can and can not do, which is proven by his words searching for help. He's got the number and general work that needs to be done, narrowed down to a general roadmap. The milestones seem understandable and reasonable if a little vague.
The timetable is a part of this proposal thatt doesn't inspire confidence, for the lack of detail. A month here, a month there seems like paiting with a broad brush. The budget seems quite reasonable for all that planned work and compared to other proposals in this challenge which are 80$ an hour, it's 37.5$ an hour are really good bargain and the value compared to price is a really good offer to be had.
I really wished there was a better roadmap that explains the concrete steps and stages of business and development, because that explanation could have brought greater understanding and credability to the project. Other than that small caveat, I really think this project is a good idea for all the reasons I've mentioned. Good luck to the proposer and I hope you get funded!
f6_assessments.q2:
There is no mention of a telegram or discord or any other formal way of communication and a way for the author to inform anyone of the progress of his proposal if it get's funded. This is a bit of an oversight as is the lack of a github repository link (even if it's empty) to the place people could turn to, checking the development progress. These are really low hanging fruits when it comes to building a community and trust between future followers and possible contributors and it seems like a missed opportinity.
There are metrics, but ony mentioned and there's no actual numbers to strive for. Number of commits and contributors is absolutely a good metric to have pointing to success, but if you just have one commit I wouldn't call that reaching the goal for tis project, but the lack of actual estimations and numbers leaves me and probably the voters wandering what is the specific end goal in numbers?
The problem and solution statements are clear and understandable and they really tackle a real problem in a way that would positively impact the community. I'd suggest to the proposer to put himself in the shoes of the voter and wander about what be expected information that's currently missing from this proposal and ask the hard questions! 
Overall I'm not sure if the regular voter would be able to easily follow along with the projects' progress because there's a lack of channels for communication.

f6_assessments.q0: Through this proposal, I can easily recognise how potential this project is. Identifying the difficulties between using Vite and PureScript in the JavaScript ecosystem and developing a tool, which helps to remove the barrier to create dapps but still ensure the quality of them, is quite a great move. Since developers do not have to struggle in building apps, more contributors will join in the Cardano Haskell projects and enlarge the ecosystem. This also can give out great opportunities for people who want to build plugins for their websites. I can see that you have the ability to spot the main challenge and have some backup plans to deal with that, which increase the reliability of this project.
f6_assessments.q1: Giving out such brief and concise breakdown of timeline and budget can help voters and the community clearly understand the process of this project. The timeline is logical and makes sense since you target one specific goal for each month, in the total of 6 months. The budget breakdown is divided into two different milestones, which is perspicuous and easy to follow. I can recognise that the author is a very talented software engineer and has experience in developing JavaScript web for 8 years but I'm still waiting to see more potential profiles of more individuals in order to know whether this team has the ability to carry out this project successfully or not.
f6_assessments.q2: The key metrics are not only very clear and understandable but also easy for voters and the community to audit. By dividing the key metrics into two different parts: one is to measure the impact and another is to indicate the project’s progress, the community can easily identify the effect of this project on the ecosystem and follow the development of it. In addition, the author also gave an instruction on how to build an app using their template, which I believe can show us the utter visualization of this project when it is delivered.

f6_assessments.q0:
I strongly agree that this proposal addresses the challenge and fits in this category. The proposal proposes to build Vite plugin for PureScript (inspired from haskell and used for web development and compiles to javascript) language. This will be open sourced and expands the web frameworks integration with Cardano (via plugins) to help fasten and simplify the onboarding/setup for web based dapps. 

The proposal gives a detailed view that aligns with the challenge settings of increasing the quality, number of open source projects.
f6_assessments.q1:
The milestones are provided w.r.t total of 6 months. First 3 months are are devoted to plugin development and subsequently the documentation, template and Prescript library covers the second half of the total timeline. The budget outlined is well explained in terms of how many developer hours are needed and estimated hourly rate boils down to $28 or so, which is quite reasonable (Since I myself have onboarded and hired many developers for companies i work(ed) for). 

Additionally, the risk areas are well explained, and a backend purescript library would be a need of an hour in order to provide full stack dapp implementation using this tech stack. Also, the technical details and plan are very well explained and the proposer itself has quite a lot of experience with the tech stack that is proposed here. Therefore, I strongly agree and good luck to the proposer.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer was responsive to my request on providing the detailed view on the auditability of this proposal. Since this proposal is about implementing the plugin and the milestones are already well explained and that the code will be open sourced, it will be fairly easy for the community to go and check the progress on github, via weekly commits and activities. 

Additionally the KPIs and success metrics are provided, with clear set of deliverables which are quantifiable. e.g. The plugin, PureScript library, Vite template. Overall, the proposal is highly auditable and hence I fully agree

f6_assessments.q0: This is a proposal that aims to build an open source tool for development of dApps with Vite  a popular frontend plugin tools based on PureScript language that is many ways similar to Haskell. It tends to open up the developers ecosystem to PureScript/ JavaScript developers. This will enable Vite plugin as an open source tool in the ecosystem to easily create and build Cardano dApps with JavaScript and by JavaScript developers thereby increasing onboarding of  more developers and promoting cross collaboration between technology solutions and Blockchains. This is welcome idea which fits into challenge settings accordingly and should be supported.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal provided adequate information as regards the plans and steps and stages of development of the project. The proposer is well experienced and competent to effectively implement this proposal and has made the necessary request for collaboration and provided solutions for any shortcomings to develop this solution. The provided budget and cost analysis as it relates to the task is reasonable and achievable within the stipulated timeframe provided in the milestones. The likely risk factors of developing and deployment of  the vite plugin into Cardano Network had been considered and solutions to mitigate them were equally provided.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has provided relevant and reliable measures and success metrics though not quantifiable, to be used to verify the progress and success of the project. The provided roadmaps can also act as good measure of assessing the development of the project.

f6_assessments.q0: A template-based framework to facilitate Cardano dAPP development will sure be useful and beneficial to the Cardano ecosystem and the community. How this will help with scalability is obvious and does not need to be explained. The additional documentation is a nice bonus as well.
f6_assessments.q1: While it becomes clear that the proposer knows what they are talking about and the overall implementation plan is sensible, it has some minor weaknesses: The proposer has not assembled a team yet and admits himself that he is not very well-versed in Plutus, which off course is a requirement. The budget however seems reasonable, even though it could be a bit more fine grained, for example diversified by the different tasks and not just the job positions. The contignency plan however is made well, as the mitigation strategies from it are already planned into the budget.
f6_assessments.q2: The problem and solution description are well made. The success criteria are go into the right direction, however their auditability would be better with the scope of the deliverables being defined more clearly and detailed. Same goes for the implementation plan, if it was clustered into more sub-tasks, auditability would benefit quite a bit.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a very interesting proposal, which, as far as I understand, intends to create a plugin for PureScript that would make it easier for JavaScript developers to write code for Cardano. PureScript is a language which is similar to Haskell, but that is more accessible to JavaScript developers (it’s a known fact that Haskell is quite difficult and underused and as such, is an entry barrier for newcomers). Even though I have over 7 years of experience in IT, my main expertise is not programming, so take my assessment with a grain of salt, but it seems to me like this person has a very good idea. This plugin that the proposer intends to create is called Vite (https://vitejs.dev) and it will help JavaScript developers transition into PureScript more comfortably (as right now there are no tools to help with this).
The impact on the ecosystem would, in my opinion, be considerable. Most of the world’s developers use JavaScript (“According to Stack Overflow's 2020 Developer Survey, JavaScript currently stands as the most commonly-used language in the world (69.7%)”). Paving the way for such a large community to start coding on Cardano would have inestimable benefits in the following years.
As a risk, the proposer identifies the fact that they may need to write a PureScript library as well to deal with Cardano server-side code, but they seem capable of doing this, so I think it’s fine.
As someone with basic JavaScript knowledge, I’m quite excited by this idea and I definitely agree this proposal effectively addresses the challenge. Score: 5.
f6_assessments.q1:
We are provided with a very simple timeline, which estimates that the work on the Vite plugin will be done in 3 months and documentation and the above-mentioned PureScript library would take another 3 months on top of that. I think a bit more work could have been done to break down what’s needed to write the plugin and the library, but it’s really a problem, just would have helped people visualize the process better.
For the budget breakdown, we are provided with an estimation of 800 work hours needed on the JavaScript / PureScript side, for 30000 USD total and another 400 hours for Plutus/Haskell work for 15000 USD. This boils down to an hourly rate of 37.5 USD, which is quite modest for a developer. I cannot make a pronouncement on the time estimates as I do not exactly understand the work which must be completed here, but the proposer seems trustworthy to me and Catalyst Funding is only released on a month to month basis, if the proposer delivers, so I think it’s fine.
The team will be composed of the proposer, Walker Gusmão, who has provided their Github (https://github.com/klarkc), where I can see a lot of activity and a Plutus/Haskell developer, which is yet to be hired. I could not find a LinkedIn page for Gusmao, but I’m willing to trust him based on the Github activity. However, as a recommendation for future proposals: always try to provide a link to a social platform, where people can find some information about you, where they can follow or contact you easily.
I think that if the proposer manages to find their Haskell developer, this proposal is highly likely to be completed successfully. Score: 5.
f6_assessments.q2:
For Auditability, in the section for measures of progress, the proposer has provided a few metrics, such as number of plugin and library downloads and number of template downloads, but I would point out to them that these are not a measure of the progress being done here, but rather of the success of the proposal. As measures of progress, the ones you mentioned below qualify (ratio of issues closed to issues opened, number of commits, number of contributors), but only partially. We would have needed these metrics to also have some targets set (for example, you could have set a target for # commits per week, or made a pledge to provide regular updates on some channel of your choosing every # weeks).
In regards to what success looks like, the proposer has simply mentioned the completion of the Plugin, the library and a Vite template (which are all valid), but in order to help the community, you could have been a bit more specific here and offered for example a demo of how the plugin works, so that the community can see it in action and see that you’ve succeeded.
All this being said, I think this is a very good initiative and I’m willing to cut the proposer some slack, because I’ve worked with developers for years and I know their strong suit isn’t selling themselves. As long as they will be reachable via some public channel, I’m sure we’ll be able to audit the progress and success of this proposal. Score: 5.
